Faculty of Maritime and Transportation Ningbo University Ningbo 315211 China dFaculty of Maritime and Transportation, Ningbo University, Ningbo, 315211, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors at: 66 West Changjiang Road, Qingdao, China. 66 West Changjiang Road Qingdao China Graphical abstract The impact of PbO on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 was studied and analyzed with BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in situ DRIFTS characterizations. The catalytic activity results showed that PbO could greatly deactivate CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. PbO could interact with Mo species to form PbMoO4 while inhibit the transformation from surface Ce4+ to Ce3+, which caused a significant decrease in the surface acidity and reducibility of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. The oxidation of NO to NO2 was suppressed owing to a decline in the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen. Additionally, the adsorption of NH3 and NO x on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was restrained. These factors were responsible for the deactivation of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst by PbO. The in situ DRIFTS results suggested that the NH3-SCR reaction on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst was governed by E-R and L-H mechanisms, which wasn’t changed by PbO. Keywords NH3-SCR NO CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 PbO 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emitted from stationary power plants and diesel vehicles will lead to diverse environmental issues including photochemical smog, acid precipitation, global warming and ozonosphere hole [1,2]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 has been widely used for removing NO x from stationary sources because of its excellent denitration performance [3]. V2O5/TiO2 catalysts modified by the oxides of W or/and Mo have been extensively applied in NH3-SCR process in the last decades owing to their excellent SCR performance [4,5]. However, there still remains some inevitable drawbacks in their practical applications, including the biotoxicity of vanadium, the inferior alkaline metals tolerance, the narrow working temperature window and low N2 selectivity at high temperature [6–8]. Therefore, it is urgent to exploit environmental-friendly SCR catalysts possessing superior deNO x performance. Cerium-based SCR catalysts have been proven to have many benefits, such as non-toxicity, outstanding oxygen storage-release capacity and redox properties, thus they are regarded as promising substitutes for vanadium-based catalysts [9,10]. In recent years, a large number of cerium-based catalysts have been reported, such as Ce/TiO2 [11], CeO2/WO3-TiO2 [12], Ce/TiZrO x [13], Ce2/Cu4Al1O x [14] and Ce-Cu/TiO2 [15]. Among these cerium-based catalysts, CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 exhibited excellent catalytic activities in a relatively wide temperature range [16–19]. Our group developed a CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst by the one-step sol-gel method and it had been demonstrated to possess glorious SCR activity even in the condition of 10 % H2O and 1000 ppm SO2 [18,19]. The NO x emission from municipal solid waste (MSW) incineration power plants is on the same order of magnitude as that from coal-fired power plants [20]. Due to the tighter constraints of NO x emission, NH3-SCR has been used in MSW incineration power plants in some developed countries. Nevertheless, numerous heavy metals are contained in the flue gas from MSW incineration plants, which will accelerate the deactivation of SCR catalysts [21]. Lead (Pb) is one of the typical deactivating species in the flue gas from coal-fired and MSW incineration power plants, which mainly exists as PbO [22]. In some MSW incineration plants, the concentration of Pb reached 6−40 mg/g in the flue gas before electrostatic dust collector [23]. In a high-dust waste incinerator, the Pb concentration over vanadia-based catalysts was up to 3350 ppm after working 80 days [24]. Therefore, the effect of PbO on SCR catalysts deserves wide public concern in the future. Our previous researches have investigated the deactivation effect of PbO on V2O5/TiO2 and CeO2/TiO2 catalysts [21,25]. The results showed that PbO could result in severe deactivation for the both catalysts, which was mainly assigned to reduced surface acidity and reducibility with the presence of PbO. For V2O5/TiO2 SCR catalyst, the poisoning effect of PbO was between that of Na2O and K2O [26]. According to the study of Khodayari and Odenbrand [20], PbO could deactivate V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts because of its rivalrous adsorption on the catalyst surface. Guo et al. [27] found that PbO could reduce chemisorbed oxygen and surface acidity over CeO2/TiO2 catalyst, leading to its deactivation. Zhou et al. [28] researched the effect of PbO on Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst and concluded that PbO could suppress the NH3 adsorption on the acid sites of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst, leading to its deactivation. From an industrial application point of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts in the future, it is urgent to research the impact of PbO on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts. In addition, it is necessary to investigate whether the addition of MoO3 has an influence on the PbO-poisoning mechanism of CeO2/TiO2. In this paper, the SCR performance of fresh and PbO-poisoning catalysts was measured to investigate the deactivation effects of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts by PbO. Furthermore, many related characterizations were carried out to research the internal reasons of the deactivation, including BET, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The fresh CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst was synthesized by a one-step sol-gel method and the mass ratio of CeO2:MoO3:TiO2 was 20:10:100. Firstly, 34 mL of tetra-n-butyl titanate mixed uniformly with 136 mL of anhydrous ethanol to form mixture A. Then 4.010 g of cerium nitrate and 0.975 g of ammonium molybdate were dissolved into 68 mL of anhydrous ethanol, 6.8 mL of nitric acid and 68 mL of deionized water to form solution B. Afterwards, A was pumped into B by a flexible peristaltic pump at a speed of 2 mL/min to form mixture C. And a yellowish transparent sol was produced after C was stirred for 3 h. Then the yellowish transparent sol was dried for 24 h (80 °C) and calcined for 5 h (500 °C) to obtain CeO2- MoO3/TiO2 catalyst (CMT). Then the fresh CMT samples were poisoned by use of an impregnation method. The fresh CMT was impregnated in an aqueous solution which contains the accurate amount of Pb(NO3)2 and the mixture was heated in a water bath of 80 °C with continuous stirring to produce pastes. Then the pastes were kept at ambient temperatures for 24 h, followed by dried overnight (110 °C) and calcined for 5 h (500 °C). The poisoned catalysts were labeled as PbOx-CMT and x represented the Pb : Ce molar ratio. 2.2 Catalytic activity A fixed-bed quartz reactor i.d. = 8 mm was used to measure the catalytic activity of the catalysts under the atmospheric pressure and the gas hourly space velocity GHSV maintained 90,000 h−1. The total flow rate of simulated gas (N2 balance) was 500 ml/min, containing 3 vol% O2, 1000 ppm NO and 1000 ppm NH3. By use of a flue gas analyzer (350 Pro, Testo), the concentrations of NO x and O2 were monitored. Due to the measured results that the concentration of N2O over the CMT and PbO1.0-CMT was lower than 6 ppm in the temperature range of 150−500 °C (see Fig. S1), N2O would not be further discussed. Furthermore, the catalytic oxidation of NO to NO2 was also measured in similar conditions without NH3 included in the simulated gas. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The BET technique by use of a N2 adsorption equipment (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020, USA) was carried out to determine the surface textural properties of all the catalysts at the temperature of 77 K. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) method were used to research the crystalline structure of the catalysts using a system with Cu Ka radiation (Rigaku D/max-2200/PC). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed by use of an electronic spectrograph with 300 W Al Ka radiations (Thermo ESCALAB 250, USA). And the carbon deposit C1S BE value (284.8 eV) was used to calibrate the binding energy. Temperature programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) and temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) were carried out on a FINESORB-3010 automatic chemical adsorption instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (FINETEC Instruments Corp.). Prior to H2-TPR tests, 0.1 g of the catalysts were exposed to the Ar flow for 1 h at the temperature of 500 °C. After that, the 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixture was introduced as the reductant and the total flow rate was 30 ml/min. In the reduction process, the temperature was increased to 700 °C from ambient temperature at a rate of 10 °C/min. Meanwhile, the TCD signal was recorded. For NH3-TPD tests, 0.1 g of the catalysts were permeated by pure ammonia (30 ml/min) for 40 min after exposure to a He stream for 1 h (500 °C), followed by sweeping with He. After that, the temperature was enhanced to 700 °C with 10 °C/min and the TCD signal was recorded at the same time. The in situ DRIFT technique was carried out using a FTIR spectrometer with a MCT detector (Thermo Nicolet iS 50). The samples were firstly exposed to a steam of Ar for 2 h at the temperature of 400 °C. Then the catalysts were gradually cooled down to 50 °C. The background spectrum was detected and deducted from the spectrum of the sample during the cooling process. The total flow rate and component of the simulated gas was the same as that of catalytic activity test in section 2.2. The FTIR spectrometer recorded the DRIFT spectrum by accumulating 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SCR activity The catalytic activities of the fresh and PbO-poisoned CMT catalysts with the increasing temperature are presented in Fig. 1 . As to the fresh CMT, the NO conversion increased sharply as the reaction temperature increased below 275 °C, and almost 100 % NO conversion was obtained at 270−450 °C. Higher temperature caused the decrease in the NO conversion of CMT. The deactivation of CMT became more and more serious with increasing PbO loadings over the whole temperature range. The highest NO conversion was only 45.1 % over PbO0.5-CMT. As for the PbO1.0-CMT, the catalytic activity was almost completely lost. It was worth noting that the NO conversion of PbO1.0-CMT decreased to below zero at 450−500 °C. The minus NO conversion might be attributed to the enhanced C-O reaction (4NH3+5O2→4NO+6H2O) at high temperatures [29]. Furthermore, the generation of N2O was found negligible. It meant that the formation of NO resulted in the drop of the selectivity of CMT in the presence of PbO. All the above results indicated that the deposition of PbO could cause the serious deactivation of CMT. 3.2 BET results The structural characteristics of the fresh and PbO-doped CMT catalysts are summarized in Table S1, involving BET surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter. It could be seen that the BET surface area and total pore volume decreased gradually as the PbO loadings increased over CMT. This agreed well with the catalytic activities in Fig. 1. Nevertheless, the average pore diameter didn’t show the same variation trend. Fig. S2 exhibits the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT. According to the IUPAC classification [30], both CMT and PbO1.0-CMT presented typical IV isotherm of mesoporous materials and the H1 type hysteresis, as shown in Fig. S2(a). From Fig. S2(b), it is found that the pore size distribution of CMT wasn’t changed in the presence of PbO, whereas the total pore volume decreased over PbO1.0-CMT, which accorded with the results in Table S1. It could be assigned to the pore blockage in the presence of PbO. These results implied that the decrease of BET surface area and total pore volume possibly worsened SCR performance of CMT, but it seemed not to be a dominant factor. 3.3 XRD results The X-ray diffraction curves of the fresh and PbO-doped CMT are presented in Fig. 2 . As for the fresh CMT, only characteristic diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 were detected, while no visible peaks corresponding to CeO2 and MoO3 were observed. It demonstrated that both CeO2 and MoO3 existed in an amorphous or highly dispersed state on the surface of anatase TiO2. For the PbO-doped CMT, new diffraction peaks assigned to PbMoO4 began to appear even with a very small amount of PbO (x = 0.05) and their intensities were enhanced with increasing PbO loadings. This suggested that there existed strong interaction between PbO and Mo species. Furthermore, two peaks of cubic CeO2 were observed over PbO1.0-CMT, suggesting that the presence of PbO could alter the dispersed state of CeO2 over CMT. Based on all the results above, it could be seen that the crystal texture of CMT was significantly changed in the presence of PbO, which would result in the worse catalytic activity. 3.4 XPS results XPS characterization was carried out to study the chemical states and atomic concentration of all elements on the surface of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT. Table 1 and Fig. 3 show the XPS results of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT. After the introduction of PbO, the surface atomic concentration of Ce decreased from 3.40 at. % to 1.50 at. % while that of Mo increased from 2.47 at. % to 2.71 at. % (see Table 1). Compared with the activity results (See Fig. 1), it could be inferred that Ce species played a major role in CMT, and Mo species mainly acted as a promoter rather than primary active species. Fig. 3(a) presents the Pb 4f XPS spectra over PbO1.0-CMT. The BE values of 4f5/2 and 4f7/2 were 143.70 and 138.84 eV, respectively. It suggested Pb species existed in the form of Pb2+ [31]. The XPS spectra of Ti 2p are presented in Fig. 3(b). For the CMT, two distinct peaks at about 464.8 eV (Ti 2p1/2) and 459.0 eV (Ti 2p3/2) were observed, respectively. It suggested that Ti existed as Ti4+ instead of Ti3+ [31]. The presence of PbO led to a slight decrease (0.1 eV) of the Ti 2p BE values. It was reported that the Ti 2p BE values of Ti3+ was 1.8 eV lower than Ti4+ [31]. Hence, Ti still existed as Ti4+ in PbO1.0-CMT. In addition, the Ti 2p XPS peaks became lower and broader on PbO1.0-CMT. This might result from the interaction between PbO and Ti. In Fig. 3(c), two peaks centered at about 236 eV (Mo 3d3/2) and 233 eV (Mo 3d5/2) were observed over the fresh CMT and PbO1.0-CMT catalysts. This indicated that Mo existed as Mo6+ [31]. The intensities of Mo 3d XPS spectra reduced after the introduction of PbO. It implied that PbO interacted with Mo species, which accorded with the XRD results. The deconvoluted XPS spectra of Ce 3d are presented in Fig. 3(d), which involved eight overlapped peaks [32]. Two peaks denoted as u′ and v′ could be assigned to surface Ce3+ corresponding to the 3d104f1 original electronic state, and the others could be ascribed to surface Ce4+ representing the 3d104f° original electronic state [32,33]. Ce3+ and Ce4+ were simultaneously present on the surface of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT. Due to the superior ability of Ce4+ to receive one electron, very mobile oxygens present in Ce species can leave the solid without changing the cationic/anionic sub-lattice structure, forming the Ce3+-Vo-Ce3+ surface local structure. This leaves behind oxygen vacancies (Vo) on the catalyst surface. Therefore, higher proportion of Ce3+ represents the formation of more unsaturated chemical bonds, charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies on catalysts surface, which would promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, and then facilitate the SCR process [34,35]. The atomic ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) was obtained from the integrated area of the peaks corresponding to Ce3+ and Ce4+. The presence of PbO led to the decrease in the atomic ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) from 0.41 to 0.29, which was consistent with the activity sequence. In addition, the intensity of the Ce 3d peaks reduced significantly after the introduction of PbO, which was indicative of the interaction between PbO and Ce species. It could be inferred that the interaction between PbO and Ce species hindered Ce4+ from trapping electron to form Ce3+. As a result, the amount of oxygen vacancies dropped and the catalytic activity was weakened. Therefore, the decrease in the amount of Ce3+ acted as a key factor responsible for the deactivation of CMT by PbO. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the decomposed O 1s XPS spectra of two catalyst samples present three distinct varieties of oxygen, involving lattice oxygen (Oα) (527.7–530.6 eV), surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) (530.6–531.1 eV) and oxygen in hydroxyl or surface adsorbed water species (Oγ) (531.1–533.5 eV) [27,36]. Compared with Oα and Oγ, Oβ played a more important role in SCR reaction due to its excellent mobility, which contributes to the NO oxidation to NO2 [37,38]. As listed in Table 1, the proportion of Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) decreased from 0.34 to 0.26 after the introduction of PbO. Therefore, the activity of CMT deceased. 3.5 NH3-TPD results In order to investigate the influence of PbO on the surface acidity of CMT, NH3-TPD experiments were carried out and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . Two distinct desorption peaks of NH3 were observed in the profile of CMT. The first wide NH3 desorption peak in the temperature range of 140 °C–500 °C was related to the NH3 desorbed by weak and medium acid sites, and the other one centered at 616 °C belonged to the desorption of NH3 molecules adsorbed on strong acid sites [39,40]. It has been established that the NH3 bound to Brønsted acid sites had worse thermostability in comparison to the coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites in the NH3-TPD process. Therefore, the broad peak at low temperatures could be ascribed to two types of Brønsted acid sites with different thermal stability while the peak at high temperature belonged to Lewis acid sites. And the surface acidity of CMT or PbO1.0-CMT could be calculated according to the peak area of the NH3-TPD profile and the results are presented in Table 2 . It can be observed that PbO resulted in the significant decrease in surface acidity of CMT. It should be also pointed out that both the desorption peaks shifted to lower temperature, indicating the interactions between PbO and surface acid sites [28]. These results implied that the deposition of PbO decreased the total amount and strength of surface acid sites (particularly Brønsted acid sites), which contributed greatly to the deactivation of CMT. 3.6 H2-TPR results H2-TPR analysis were performed to compare the reduction behavior of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . As for the CMT, the onset of reduction was observed at about 308 °C. It exhibited a prominent reduction peak centered at about 513 °C, which could be attributed to the co-reduction of Ce4+ and Mo6+ species [16,41]. The introduction of PbO resulted in a shift of the onset temperature of reduction to higher temperature (about 348 °C). It implied that surface species on PbO1.0-CMT were difficult to be reduced than those on CMT. In other words, the reduction of surface Ce4+ and Mo6+ species was suppressed. The profile of PbO1.0-CMT consisted of two overlapped peaks at 498 °C and 564 °C. The difference in the H2-TPR profiles of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT might be due to the interaction between PbO and CMT. The relative reduction area and H2 consumption were calculated and listed in Table 3 . It was clear that the relative reduction area and H2 consumption decreased after the introduction of PbO. It indicated the worse reducibility of PbO1.0-CMT, which was a major factor leading to the deactivation of CMT by PbO. 3.7 NO oxidation to NO2 The oxidation of NO to NO2 was proven to have a positive effect on the NH3-SCR reaction [25,42]. Therefore, the measurement of NO oxidation to NO2 was performed over the CMT and PbO1.0-CMT with the results shown in Fig. 6 . It was clear that the activities of NO oxidation to NO2 was significantly inhibited with the introduction of PbO, which was consistent with the SCR performance in Fig.1. It had been proven that chemisorbed oxygen could promote the oxidation of NO to NO2 [43], thus the decreased NO oxidation activities of CMT should be resulted from the reduced chemisorbed oxygen by PbO. This agreed well with the O1 s XPS analysis. 3.8 In situ DRIFT experiments 3.8.1 NH3 adsorption The in situ DRIFT experiments of NH3 adsorption were carried out to identify the surface acid sites of different catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . For the fresh CMT catalyst, the band at 1436 cm−1 was ascribed to NH4 + species over Brønsted acid sites and two bands at 1600 cm−1 and 1221 cm−1 could be assigned to NH3 species coordinated to Lewis acid sites [44,45]. Three small bands within 3150−3400 cm−1 could be attributed to NH stretching vibration modes [46,47]. It could be found that the band at 1436 cm−1 decreased remarkably as temperatures increased and nearly vanished at the temperature of 300 °C, whereas the bands at 1600 cm−1 and 1221 cm−1 were still present at 350 °C. This indicated that Brønsted acid sites had lower thermal stability than Lewis acid sites. From Fig.7 (b), it was observed that the band intensities reduced after the presence of PbO, particularly the band intensities of Brønsted acid sites. These results demonstrated that the NH3 adsorption over both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites was restrained by PbO, especially that on Brønsted acid sites, which conformed to the NH3-TPD results. Based on the formation of PbMoO4 (XRD results) and the decrease in the amount of surface Ce3+ (XPS results), it could be reasonably inferred that Brønsted acid sites were originated from well dispersed Mo species and surface Ce3+, whereas Lewis acid sites was mainly provided by surface Ce4+ [6,13,48]. 3.8.2 NO + O2 co-adsorption The NO + O2 co-adsorption DRIFT spectra are presented as Fig. 8 . The band at 1623 cm−1 was ascribed to adsorbed NO2 species while the two bands at 1580 and 1230 cm−1 was due to bidentate nitrate (Fig. 8(a)) [6,49]. For the PbO1.0-CMT, two bands belonging to adsorbed NO2 (1617 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1563 cm−1) were observed (Fig. 8(b)). However, the intensities were weakened significantly. It indicated that the adsorption of NO x species and the NO oxidation to NO2 were restrained by PbO, which might result from the reduced surface chemisorbed oxygen, as analyzed in XPS results. This agreed well with the NO oxidation activity to NO2 (See Fig. 6). It is accepted that the oxidation of NO to NO2 would contribute to the SCR process via a “fast SCR” route [50]. Therefore, the inhibited NO x adsorption (especially the adsorbed NO2) would aggravate the deactivation of CMT by PbO. 3.8.3 Reaction between NOx and pre-adsorbed NH3 species The reaction between NO x and pre-adsorbed NH3 species over the fresh CMT and PbO1.0-CMT catalyst samples were carried out at 250 °C and the in situ DRIFT spectra are presented in Fig. 9 . After pretreated by NH3 for 30 min and N2 purification for 15 min, several NH3 adsorption peaks due to NH4 + species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (1435 cm−1), NH3 species coordinated to Lewis acid sites (1600 cm-1 and 1223 cm−1) and NH stretching vibration modes (3363 cm−1, 3265 cm-1 and 3165 cm−1) were detected. After NO + O2 was imported into the IR cell, the intensity of all the bands distinctly deceased with time and the band ascribed to adsorbed NO2 (1619 cm−1) was detected. It suggested that the ammonia species on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were active in NH3-SCR reaction and could react with gaseous NO/NO x adspecies. Similar DRIFT spectra were recorded for PbO1.0-CMT, as presented in Fig. 9(b). However, the intensity of NH3 adsorption peaks decreased significantly. It meant that PbO could inhibit the adsorption of NH3 on the surface of CMT. After NO + O2 was introduced into the IR cell, all the NH3 adsorption bands vanished with 10 min, which was similar to the fresh CMT. Therefore, it could be inferred that PbO could restrain the adsorption of NH3 on the surface of CMT, but not change the reactivity of the adsorbed NH3. Thus Eley-Rideal (E–R) mechanism was suitable to the NH3-SCR reaction of CMT and PbO1.0-CMT. 3.8.4 Reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NOx species Fig. 10 presents the in situ DRIFT spectra of the reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO + O2 species. The band due to adsorbed NO2 species (1615 cm−1) was observed after CMT was exposed to NO + O2 for 30 min. However, the band disappeared within 2 min after the import of NH3, followed by the appearance of characteristic peak assigned to NH3 species. Similar phenomena were recorded on PbO1.0-CMT despite the decreased intensities of all the bands. This indicated that all the NO x species adsorbed on the catalyst surface was active in NH3-SCR process and the presence of PbO didn’t alter the reactivity of adsorbed NO x species. Based on the analysis above, the NH3-SCR reaction of CMT was also controlled by Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism [51]. 3.9 Reaction mechanism The NH3-SCR reaction over fresh CMT catalyst was controlled by a union of E-R and L-H mechanism on the basis of in situ DRIFT experiments, described as Eqs. (1)–(6). The presence of PbO only suppressed the adsorption of NO x and NH3 species, yet the reaction mechanism wasn’t altered. (a) E-R mechanism (1) N H 3 ( a ) ⟶ C e 3 + , M o s p e c i e s N H 4 + ( a ) (2) N H 4 + ( a ) ⟶ S u r f a c e O N H 2 ( a ) + 2 H + + e (3) N H 2 ( a ) + N O ( g ) → N H 2 N O ( a ) → N 2 + H 2 O (a) L-H mechanism (4) N O ( g ) + O ( s u r f ) → N O 2 ( a ) (5) N H 3 ( g ) ⟶ C e 4 + N H 3 ( a ) (6) N H 3 ( a ) + N O 2 ( a ) + N O ( g ) → N 2 + H 2 O The XRD results revealed that PbO destroyed the amorphous state of Mo species and led to the formation of PbMoO4. And the transformation from Ce4+ to Ce3+ was significantly restrained, as pointed in Ce 3d XPS analysis. These caused a great decrease in the amount of Brønsted acid sites, which would suppress Eqs. (1) and (2) in E-R mechanism. Based on the results of NH3-TPD and DRIFT of NH3 adsorption, Brønsted acid sites acted as the main acid sites over CMT catalyst. Then the reduced Brønsted acid sites was a main factor responsible for the deactivation of CMT by PbO. From the results of the NO oxidation to NO2 and DRIFT of NO + O2 co-adsorption, the deposition of PbO weakened the oxidation of NO to NO2, indicating that Eq. (4) was inhibited. This could be ascribed to the reduced surface chemisorbed oxygen, as analyzed in XPS results. As a result, Eq. (6) of the L-H mechanism was strongly restrained. This was another reason for the deactivation of CMT. Additionally, the NH3 adsorption over Lewis acid sites was also suppressed by the presence of PbO, which exacerbated the catalytic activities of CMT catalyst. On the basis of above discussions, a possible principle scheme of PbO poisoning on CMT catalyst was forecasted in Fig. 11 . 4 Conclusion PbO led to a serious deactivation of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. The fresh and PbO-doped CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFT. Unlike the BET surface area and total pore volume, the average pore diameter did not show the same variation trend as the catalytic activity. The physical properties of the catalysts were not the dominant factor for their deactivation by PbO. The worse dispersion of CeO2 species, the strong interaction between PbO and CMT, the decrease in surface Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen, the loss of surface acidity and the degradation of reducibility contributed to the deactivation of CMT by PbO. The oxidation of NO to NO2 was suppressed owing to a decline in the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen. Additionally, the results of NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFT revealed that PbO inhibited the adsorption of NH3 and NO x on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The NH3-SCR reaction on CMT was still governed by E-R and L-H mechanisms, which wasn’t changed by PbO. coredata.dc:description: The impact of PbO on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 was studied and analyzed with BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in situ DRIFTS characterizations. The catalytic activity results showed that PbO could greatly deactivate CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. PbO could interact with Mo species to form PbMoO4 while inhibit the transformation from surface Ce4+ to Ce3+, which caused a significant decrease in the surface acidity and reducibility of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. The oxidation of NO to NO2 was suppressed owing to a decline in the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen. Additionally, the adsorption of NH3 and NO x on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was restrained. These factors were responsible for the deactivation of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst by PbO. The in situ DRIFTS results suggested that the NH3-SCR reaction on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst was governed by E-R and L-H mechanisms, which wasn’t changed by PbO.
coredata.dc:title: The poisoning effect of PbO on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
